awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Quantum Manufacturing: Robust Atom-based Silicon Quantum Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) Quantum Manufacturing award supports research to expand manufacturing processes for semiconductor electronic and quantum devices by advancing the science needed to manufacture devices down to the size-scale approaching single atoms. The results of this research will enable manufacturing of semiconductor devices at size scales not possible today, advancing national prosperity and security. A scanning tunneling microscope is used as a fabrication tool to deterministically place individual phosphorus dopant atoms in silicon with near lattice site perfection. Atomic-scale gates and leads for few atom transistors, dopant-based few-atom qubit devices and dopant arrays for analog quantum simulation can now be fabricated for scientific experiments. The exact positions of dopants play an essential role in device performance, driving the need for atomic perfection. Current imprecision in dopant concentration or dopant position still prevents robust manufacturing. Atom-based silicon quantum devices have generated excitement because they promise to provide the smallest, most dense quantum devices while still leveraging the power of traditional silicon electronics. Robust atom-based silicon quantum devices require advanced manufacturing with precise control over the number and precision of dopant placement. The work here will push traditional nanoscale manufacturing science toward robust atom-scale manufacturing where silicon-based devices can be routinely fabricated atom-by-atom. The research will accelerate manufacturing into the realm of atom-scale devices. Developing robust manufacturing of atom-scale solid state quantum devices will help address the critical national need for successful quantum platforms that can be integrated with conventional electronics.

Feedback-controlled lithography was developed to allow atom-scale perfect placement of an individual phosphorus (P) dopant on silicon (Si). This research will advance from one-time demonstrations of perfect placement to robust precise placement of individual atoms that can be used to manufacture atom-scale solid-state Si devices. Perfect placement will be extended to acceptors like boron (B). This additional capability will provide a wider class of quantum devices that can be manufactured and exploited. Density functional theory will be used to simulate scanning tunneling images and determine preferred adsites for B2H6 and its breakdown species. A similar catalog of images will be generated for two-donor and two-acceptor structures. The catalogs will be used to identify deposited structures and new feedback control will be developed to ensure precise placement of B acceptors and multi-dopant structures. Transport and related experiments on these devices will be performed and compared to theory to verify the precision fabrication of atom geometries as designed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes: Quantum Manufacturing: Robust Atom-based Silicon Quantum Devices

 

Imagine building a quantum device or a nanoscale point-defect sensor or even a material layer atom-by-atom, placing each atom that you want where you want it with atom-scale precision. This atom-by-atom fabrication would be the ultimate level of control. The research described here, conducted by researchers in the NIST/University of Maryland Joint Quantum Institute and supported by an NSF EAGER grant, is pushing toward this ultimate level of fabrication. The goal is both to make a tool for research and to create manufacturing processes for making atom-scale quantum devices for quantum computing, simulation and sensing in silicon. Previous research over nearly two decades has developed nearly perfect placement of phosphorous donors in silicon. As shown in the cartoon, a metallic tip, used for scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), is used to clear off hydrogen atoms passivating the silicon surface to create patches of dangling bonds. Phosphine molecules (PH3) are deposited in the patches and the phosphorous atom from a molecule replaces a silicon surface atom. A single, deposited phosphorous atom can be used as a qubit (image 2 in the cartoon), a larger collection (region 1 in the cartoon) serves as a sensor of the charge on the qubit, while other collections (3 and 4) provide leads to connect to external circuits. Recently, we developed techniques that ensured near perfect placement of the phosphorous atom exactly where it is designed to be, greatly improving the placement process. The key was using the STM tip to image the deposition and then comparing with simulated images (as shown in the cartoon) to ensure that the deposition was proceeding exactly as desired and then using the tip for feedback control to direct the process, if needed, to the desired placement.

Perfect placement of just phosphorous dopants is not enough to build the quantum devices, point defect sensors or materials that we want. In the research reported here we have extended perfect placement to include the placement of boron, an acceptor, on the silicon surface. Boron as an acceptor in silicon, has very different properties from phosphorous. Being able to deposit both donors and acceptors with atom-scale precision greatly extends the range of atom-scale quantum devices and point defects that could be fabricated. Importantly, our results show that feedback control can be used to increase the number of dopants that can be deposited, suggesting a path for perfect placement of many dopants.  In addition, we have demonstrated that we can place exactly one dopant at a silicon site, or two dopants next to each other using feedback control. Controlling the number and the geometry of the dopants placed is another way to create hybrid clusters with engineered properties that could be exploited to fabricate designer, atom-scale quantum devices.

Feedback control with a person directing the STM tip movement is time intensive. To make this a robust, efficient, viable manufacturing process, we are automating the process. During this work, we have automated the process to recondition/repair the STM tip being used. This is important for feedback control because the feedback is determined after imaging the processing to see what has been done. This step relies on having a good tip that produces accurate images. Our tip conditioning process uses a trained convolutional neural network (CNN) to identify when the STM tip is unable to function as intended. For feedback control, the tip must be able to image device fabrication progress, must be capable of creating precise lithographic features, and must be capable of manipulating adsorbed species.  This automated routine images a small region of the surface (50nm x 50nm or less), assesses the tip quality, and if the tip needs to be conditioned it then moves to a predefined conditioning location and performs operations that are known to change the apex of the tip (voltage pulses and gentle pokes into the silicon surface). This process continues until the tip is determined by the CNN to be sufficiently improved. This approach of automating the fabrication processes, where the controller frequently assesses the quality of both the tip and currently fabricated structures and makes corrections as errors occur, will provide repeatable and robust atom-by-atom fabrication.

We are now using this perfect dopant placement to make atom-scale dopant arrays in silicon to do analog quantum simulation of Hubbard models and lattice gauge theory. Previously we did these simulations with imperfect arrays strongly affected by disorder. Now we are making what we want to simulate. We have now started theoretical simulations of phosphorous/boron dopant complexes to design target point defects for perfect dopant placement. The people being trained in perfect dopant placement to do this work will provide the next generation of leaders in atom-by-atom manufacturing of atom-scale quantum devices.
